title: Netflix Advertising Strategy Analysis
text: Course: BUSI 654 ‚Äì Application of AI in Business Type: Individual Business Report Year: 2025

title: Netflix Advertising Strategy Analysis
text:
Project Overview
This project explores how large language models (LLMs) can be leveraged for business strategy development. I analyzed Netflix‚Äôs advertising landscape and developed a comprehensive marketing campaign for their ad-supported subscription tier.
What started as a straightforward business analysis became an interesting exploration of how AI tools can enhance‚Äîbut not replace‚Äîstrategic thinking. I used LLMs primarily as brainstorming partners and research assistants, but the strategic decisions, creative direction, and final analysis remained distinctly human-driven.
Key Challenge: How can we balance AI assistance with authentic strategic thinking to create actionable business recommendations?

title: Netflix Advertising Strategy Analysis
text:
Why Netflix and Why Now?
I chose Netflix‚Äôs ad-supported tier for three specific reasons that made this project personally interesting:
1. Market Timing: Netflix launched their ad-supported plan in late 2022, which means we‚Äôre still in the early adoption phase. This timing creates a unique opportunity to analyze real-time strategy adjustments rather than just retrospective case studies.
2. Industry Disruption: Netflix spent years positioning itself as ‚Äúad-free premium entertainment,‚Äù then reversed course. This strategic pivot fascinates me because it shows how even industry leaders must adapt to market pressures (subscriber losses, competition, revenue needs).
3. Personal Context: As an MBA student in hospitality management, I‚Äôm drawn to businesses that balance service excellence with financial sustainability. Netflix‚Äôs challenge mirrors what I see in senior living operations‚Äîhow do you maintain quality experience while managing different pricing tiers?

What Makes This Different from Typical Case Studies?
Most Netflix case studies focus on content strategy or subscriber metrics. I deliberately chose to focus on the advertising psychology and campaign design because: - There‚Äôs less existing analysis (more room for original thinking) - It connects to my interest in customer behavior across demographics - The ad-supported tier requires understanding both advertisers AND viewers‚Äîa dual-customer challenge I find compelling

title: Netflix Advertising Strategy Analysis
text:
Research Methodology: Working with LLMs

My Approach to AI-Assisted Research
I used ChatGPT (GPT-4) and Claude as research assistants, but I quickly learned that effective LLM use requires strategic prompting rather than passive questioning.
What worked well: - Using LLMs to generate competitor comparison frameworks - Asking for demographic research on 18‚Äì38 age groups‚Äô media habits - Brainstorming unconventional campaign messaging angles
What didn‚Äôt work: - Generic prompts like ‚Äúanalyze Netflix advertising‚Äù produced surface-level responses - LLMs sometimes invented statistics that seemed plausible but weren‚Äôt real - Creative campaign ideas from LLMs often felt safe and uninspired
This led me to develop a two-stage verification process:

First Pass: Use LLM to generate ideas and structure
Second Pass: Verify every claim against actual sources (annual reports, Statista, Nielsen data, marketing journals)

The result? About 30% of LLM-generated content made it to the final report‚Äîthe rest was either too generic, unverifiable, or lacked strategic nuance.

title: Netflix Advertising Strategy Analysis
text:
Question Development & Strategic Framework

The Core Questions I Asked
Rather than asking surface-level questions like ‚ÄúWhat is Netflix‚Äôs target audience?‚Äù I developed three strategic questions that required synthesis and analysis:

Question 1: How has Netflix‚Äôs brand identity shifted with the introduction of ads, and what does this mean for long-term subscriber perception?
Why this question matters: Netflix built its reputation on ad-free viewing. Introducing ads isn‚Äôt just a revenue tactic‚Äîit‚Äôs a fundamental brand repositioning. I wanted to understand the psychological trade-offs.
Alternatives considered: - ‚ÄúWhat are Netflix‚Äôs main competitors?‚Äù (Too descriptive, no analysis) - ‚ÄúHow successful is the ad-supported tier?‚Äù (Too early for conclusive data)
What I discovered: The shift reveals a tension between premium positioning and accessibility. Netflix is essentially creating a two-tier class system among subscribers. This echoes what I‚Äôve observed in hospitality‚Äîwhen you create tiers, you must carefully manage how each segment perceives value.


Question 2: What messaging strategy can make ads feel less like an interruption and more like an acceptable trade-off for cost savings?
Why this question matters: Most analysis focuses on whether to introduce ads. I wanted to explore how to message them. This is a human psychology question, not just a business question.
Creative angles explored: - Positioning ads as ‚Äúsupporting creators‚Äù (didn‚Äôt feel authentic for Netflix) - Emphasizing cost savings (too transactional, lacks emotional resonance) - Final choice: ‚ÄúWatch more, pay less‚Äù campaign (balances practicality with lifestyle benefit)


Question 3: Which advertising channels best reach price-sensitive younger viewers who still value premium content?
Why this question matters: The target audience (18‚Äì38, budget-conscious but quality-seeking) exists across multiple platforms. Rather than defaulting to ‚Äúsocial media advertising,‚Äù I wanted to explore channel-specific strategies.
Unconventional insight: TikTok isn‚Äôt just a channel for ads‚Äîit‚Äôs a content discovery platform. I proposed partnering with creators who make ‚Äúwhat I watched this month‚Äù content, which feels native rather than promotional.

title: Netflix Advertising Strategy Analysis
text:
Campaign Development: ‚ÄúWatch More, Pay Less‚Äù

The Strategic Rationale
Most streaming service ads emphasize content breadth (‚Äúthousands of shows!‚Äù). I noticed this approach commodifies Netflix‚Äîit makes them sound interchangeable with other services.
Instead, I developed ‚ÄúWatch More, Pay Less‚Äù to emphasize a lifestyle benefit: - ‚ÄúWatch More‚Äù implies guilt-free binge-watching and time for yourself - ‚ÄúPay Less‚Äù positions ads as an empowering choice, not a compromise


Why This Resonated with Me
Having worked in hospitality and senior living, I‚Äôve seen how small language shifts change customer perception. In retirement homes, we don‚Äôt say ‚Äúassisted living‚Äù‚Äîwe say ‚Äúsupportive living‚Äù because it maintains dignity and autonomy.
Similarly, ‚ÄúWatch More, Pay Less‚Äù doesn‚Äôt say ‚Äúcheap tier with ads‚Äù‚Äîit says ‚Äúsmart choice for savvy viewers.‚Äù


Media Mix Strategy
I designed a channel strategy based on where the target audience actually spends time:
Digital Channels (70% of budget): - YouTube pre-roll (reaches viewers already in ‚Äúwatching‚Äù mode) - Meta/Instagram Stories (visual, quick, scrollable format) - TikTok creator partnerships (native, authentic recommendations)
Traditional Media (30% of budget): - Spotify/podcast ads (captures commuters and multitaskers) - Selected transit ads in urban areas (targets young professionals)
Why not TV ads? The target audience is cord-cutters. TV advertising would contradict the insight that they‚Äôve already left traditional TV behind.

title: Netflix Advertising Strategy Analysis
section: LLM Responses: What AI Generated vs.¬†What I Used
text:
LLM Responses: What AI Generated vs.¬†What I Used

Section Purpose
This section shows how I used LLM outputs as raw material rather than final content. Understanding what AI generates versus what requires human judgment is critical for ethical AI use in business.


Example 1: Target Audience Analysis
LLM Initial Response: > ‚ÄúNetflix‚Äôs ad-supported tier targets budget-conscious consumers aged 18-35 who want access to premium content at a lower price point. These users are typically young professionals, students, and families.‚Äù
Why this wasn‚Äôt sufficient: - Too generic (could describe any streaming service) - Missed psychographic details (values, behaviors, motivations) - Lacked competitive context
My Refined Analysis: The primary audience is price-sensitive but quality-conscious viewers aged 18‚Äì38 who: - Grew up with streaming (no nostalgia for cable TV) - Subscribe to multiple services but experience ‚Äúsubscription fatigue‚Äù - Value content curation over content volume - Are active on social media and trust peer recommendations over traditional ads
This group isn‚Äôt ‚Äúcheap‚Äù‚Äîthey‚Äôre strategic about spending. They‚Äôll pay for quality (hence choosing Netflix over free options) but seek value optimization (hence choosing ad-supported over premium).


Example 2: Campaign Messaging
LLM Initial Response: > ‚ÄúEmphasize the vast library of content available at a fraction of the cost. Highlight popular shows and movies to demonstrate value.‚Äù
Why this felt generic: - Focus on content catalog (what every streaming service says) - Transactional framing (lacks emotional connection) - Doesn‚Äôt address the ‚Äúads‚Äù part (avoids the main friction point)
My Creative Direction: Instead of avoiding ads, acknowledge them directly with humor and honesty:
Sample ad copy: ‚ÄúYeah, there are ads. But your wallet will thank you. Watch more guilt-free Netflix. Pay less guilt-inducing bills.‚Äù
This approach: - Disarms the negative (honesty builds trust) - Uses humor (makes ads feel less serious) - Balances practical benefit (lower cost) with emotional benefit (guilt-free enjoyment)


What This Comparison Reveals
LLMs excel at structure and breadth but struggle with nuance and originality. They generate ‚Äúsafe‚Äù responses that sound professional but lack distinctive voice or strategic risk-taking.
The transition from LLM output to final strategy required: 1. Specificity: Adding demographic and psychographic details 2. Context: Connecting to broader industry trends and competitive dynamics 3. Creativity: Introducing unexpected angles (humor, honesty, lifestyle framing) 4. Voice: Writing in a tone that reflects how real people think, not how AI thinks business documents should sound

title: Netflix Advertising Strategy Analysis
section: Human Evaluation: Assessing Quality Beyond AI Metrics
text:
Human Evaluation: Assessing Quality Beyond AI Metrics

Why Human Evaluation Mattered
After generating and refining LLM content, I needed to evaluate whether my final strategy actually worked. AI can generate text, but it can‚Äôt assess strategic soundness or market fit.
I developed a three-layer evaluation framework:

Layer 1: Logical Coherence
Question: Does the strategy internally make sense?
Evaluation Method: I created a logic map connecting: - Target audience traits ‚Üí Campaign messaging ‚Üí Channel selection ‚Üí Expected outcomes
Findings: Initial messaging focused too heavily on cost savings without addressing the psychological barrier of ads. This created a logical gap: if people were purely cost-driven, they‚Äôd choose free streaming services instead.
Adjustment: Shifted messaging to emphasize lifestyle trade-off (‚ÄúWatch more guilt-free content‚Äù) rather than pure cost savings.


Layer 2: Market Realism
Question: Would this actually work in Netflix‚Äôs competitive environment?
Evaluation Method: Compared my strategy against real campaigns by Disney+, Hulu, and Peacock (all offer ad-supported tiers).
Surprising Finding: Most competitors focus on content exclusivity (‚ÄúOnly on Disney+‚Äù). Netflix‚Äôs strength isn‚Äôt exclusive content anymore‚Äîit‚Äôs curation and recommendation.
Strategic Implication: My campaign should emphasize Netflix‚Äôs ability to ‚Äúknow what you‚Äôll love‚Äù rather than competing on content breadth. The ads don‚Äôt interrupt this value‚Äîthey subsidize it.


Layer 3: Personal Stress-Testing
Question: Would I believe this campaign if I saw it?
Evaluation Method: I role-played as three different viewer personas: 1. Budget-conscious student (me 5 years ago) 2. Young professional (me now, juggling MBA + work) 3. Parent (not me, but representing family subscribers)
Result: As a budget-conscious student, the campaign would resonate because it validates a smart financial choice. As a young professional, I‚Äôd appreciate honesty about ads rather than corporate spin. As a parent, I‚Äôd want reassurance that ad content is family-appropriate (a gap I added to implementation notes).



What I Learned About Human Judgment
This evaluation process taught me that strategy isn‚Äôt just about being correct‚Äîit‚Äôs about being believable. LLMs generate ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù content, but humans assess credibility, emotional resonance, and practical feasibility.
Key Realization: The best campaigns don‚Äôt just present information‚Äîthey anticipate objections and address them preemptively. The ‚ÄúYeah, there are ads‚Äù messaging came from this human evaluation phase, not from LLM brainstorming.

title: Netflix Advertising Strategy Analysis
text:
Metrics & Success Indicators

How I‚Äôd Measure Campaign Effectiveness
Most business reports list generic metrics (awareness, engagement, conversion). I developed metrics tied to specific strategic goals:

Primary Metrics (What success looks like in 6 months):
1. Ad-Tier Subscriber Growth Rate - Target: 15% quarter-over-quarter growth - Why this matters: Proves the messaging resonates with target audience
2. Conversion from Free Trial to Paid Ad-Tier - Target: 60% conversion rate - Why this matters: Shows the experience matches expectations (ads aren‚Äôt worse than anticipated)
3. Churn Rate Comparison (Ad-Tier vs.¬†Premium) - Target: No more than 5% difference - Why this matters: If ad-tier churn is significantly higher, the trade-off isn‚Äôt balanced


Secondary Metrics (What predicts long-term success):
4. Ad Engagement Rate - Target: 70% of ads watched to completion - Why this matters: If viewers constantly skip ads, the product isn‚Äôt sustainable for advertisers
5. Cross-Grade Rate (Ad-Tier to Premium) - Target: 10% annual upgrade rate - Why this matters: Creates upsell pipeline and validates the ‚Äúladder‚Äù strategy
6. Social Sentiment Analysis - Target: Positive sentiment (‚â•60%) on campaign-related social posts - Why this matters: Young audiences trust peer opinions over corporate metrics



Unconventional Metric I Proposed
‚ÄúTime to First Ad Complaint‚Äù - Measure how long into free trial before users comment about ads - Hypothesis: If complaints come in first week, onboarding messaging is insufficient. If they come after 3+ weeks, messaging was effective.
This metric isn‚Äôt standard, but it captures something important: expectation management. The goal isn‚Äôt zero complaints‚Äîit‚Äôs informed complaints (users knew what they signed up for).

title: Netflix Advertising Strategy Analysis
section: What I‚Äôd Do Differently: Honest Reflection
text:
What I‚Äôd Do Differently: Honest Reflection

Limitations I Encountered
1. Over-Reliance on LLM Structure in Early Drafts My first outline came directly from ChatGPT. It was logical but generic. I spent significant time unlearning the AI‚Äôs organizational framework to create something more distinctive.
Lesson: Start with human brainstorming, then use AI to fill gaps‚Äînot the reverse.
2. Difficulty Verifying Demographic Claims LLMs confidently cite statistics that don‚Äôt exist. I spent hours trying to verify a claim about ‚ÄúGen Z streaming habits‚Äù before realizing it was AI-generated fiction.
Lesson: Treat all LLM claims as hypotheses requiring verification.
3. Creative Ideas Felt ‚ÄúSafe‚Äù When I asked LLMs for campaign ideas, responses were professionally adequate but uninspired. The ‚ÄúWatch More, Pay Less‚Äù tagline came from my own brainstorming after midnight when I stopped trying to sound ‚Äúbusiness-like.‚Äù
Lesson: AI outputs often reflect the average of its training data‚Äîwhich means they avoid creative risk.


What I‚Äôm Curious About for Future Work
1. Long-term brand impact: How will introducing ads affect Netflix‚Äôs premium tier positioning 5 years from now? Does creating a two-tier system erode the ‚Äúprestige‚Äù factor?
2. Ad content curation: Could Netflix differentiate by making ads actually relevant and non-intrusive? (Spotify does this well‚ÄîNetflix could too)
3. International rollout: My analysis focused on North America. How would this campaign adapt for markets with different attitudes toward ads?

title: Netflix Advertising Strategy Analysis
section: Final Thoughts: AI as a Tool, Not a Substitute
text:
Final Thoughts: AI as a Tool, Not a Substitute
This project reinforced something I‚Äôve observed in my hospitality work: technology enhances human service but can‚Äôt replace human judgment.
LLMs are powerful brainstorming partners. They accelerate research, suggest frameworks, and generate options I wouldn‚Äôt have considered. But the strategic decisions‚Äîwhat to emphasize, how to message, what risks to take‚Äîrequired human intuition, market sense, and personal judgment.
The most valuable part of this project wasn‚Äôt the final strategy document. It was learning to interrogate AI outputs critically: - When is this generic? - Where‚Äôs the distinctive insight? - Would I believe this if someone else wrote it?
As I move toward management roles in hospitality and senior living, I expect AI tools to become more prevalent. This project gave me a framework for using them effectively: leverage AI for breadth, then add human depth.

text:
Personal Takeaway
This wasn‚Äôt just a business project‚Äîit was a lesson in critical thinking in the age of AI. The most marketable skill isn‚Äôt knowing how to use ChatGPT. It‚Äôs knowing when its outputs are sufficient, when they need refinement, and when they should be discarded entirely.
That‚Äôs the kind of judgment that will matter in management roles‚Äîand it‚Äôs something AI can‚Äôt replicate.
